channel.title: upgrade heatsink?
channel.description: Hello I have a Core 2 Duo Wolfdale 3.0ghz prossesor and, I want to overclock it heavily. Can somebody recommend to me the best heatsink for this prossesor? Thank you. :slight_smile:

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
If you properly insulate the board there should be no problem.
What are you basing this supposed problem on?

EDIT: Also, there are few refrigerators that use more than a single stage of refrigeration process, and they also use a different refrigerant chemicals.

Read full topic

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: Samapico
item.description:
Sure, if you keep it at -200 C or whatever, you get better conductivity. But you only use liquid nitrogen when you actually run the CPU, so it gets shifted from ambiant temperature to -200, to ambiant again at each use. Temperature changes like that can’t be good to anything.

Wikipedia:

[…] In the realm of personal computers, this method of cooling is seldom used in contexts other than overclocking trial-runs and record-setting attempts, as the CPU will usually expire within a relatively short period of time due to temperature stress caused by changes in internal temperature.

On phase change:
Also, it’s not just the use of refrigerant gas… it works exactly the same way as a refrigerator or freezer. It’s not “super powered” unless you use a 10 HP compressor or something (good luck plugging that in your 120V outlet). A normal freezer can be much colder than what it usually is… These things are actually working like 5% of the time.

Read full topic

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
Samapico:

These liquid gas will kill your CPU in no time, though. Think of the brutal temperature changes

Phase change is just a fancy way of saying a refrigerator, basically…

Neither of those statements are really correct. The cooler a circuit gets the less migration that goes on and the longer your CPU lasts. It’s heat that causes migration, which destroys your CPU.

Also, just because something uses refrigerant gas doesn’t mean it’s a simple household refrigerator. Though I guess you could say it’s a super powered refrigerator.

Read full topic

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: Samapico
item.description:
These liquid gas will kill your CPU in no time, though. Think of the brutal temperature changes

Phase change is just a fancy way of saying a refrigerator, basically…

Read full topic

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
No phase change isn’t THE coolest. Even LN2 isn’t THE coldest ( I forget if it was liquid helium or something else that goes that extra tiny bit). I would say though that liquid cooling isn’t even in the ballpark though. To say it’s ‘the best’ when it’s the best at nothing bothered me.

Read full topic

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: Kaze
item.description:
MaxTheLimit:

Hey you cut off the part where I said ‘easiest’!

Does he seem like someone who should be handling LN2 on a regular basis?

Because LN2 isn’t the easiest, but phase change certainly isn’t the coolest. Difficulty is irrelevant when you’re comparing e-penis length.

Read full topic

item.title: upgrade heatsink?
item.dc:creator: MaxTheLimit
item.description:
Samapico:

It’s silent, and you can pretty much make it dump the heat somewhere else than in your face.
But cooling-wise, are you saying air is better than water cooling? Or are you implying of other ridiculous things like sinking your computer in a liquid nitrogen pool?

When you say such things, it’s usually fun if you provide stats, links, or examples… To counter an opinion with a different opinion, without any argument, is pretty useless. I don’t know/care who is right or not, btw.

I guess I could go into more detail, but the very idea that water is ‘the best’ is just totally out there. Water cooling isn’t ‘the best’ at anything. It is far from the coolest running, and it is far from the most convenient. Phase change is the coolest and easiest way to get sum zero temperatures, and can do it for less than 200 bucks. You can get a chilly1 unit for that price and it will get below -200C on the core in some cases. It’s far simpler to get running as well.

The easiest is air cooling of course, because of the low cost and rather impressive capabilities of modern air coolers.

The one thing water set ups have is only slightly cooler temps, that don’t really make much difference in the end, and silence. But with modern silent high CFM fans, that point is becoming greatly irrelevant.

Read full topic

But cooling-wise, are you saying air is better than water cooling? Or are you implying of other ridiculous things like sinking your computer in a liquid nitrogen pool?

When you say such things, it’s usually fun if you provide stats, links, or examples… To counter an opinion with a different opinion, without any argument, is pretty useless. I don’t know/care who is right or not, btw.
